IntroductionCLOUDSORT CORPORATION (“CloudSort”) is created for our e-commerce world. It provides “middle mile” software, sortation and transportation services that are designed from the ground up to serve e-commerce. Core to the CloudSort proposition is a cloud-based sortation software platform (“CloudSort System”). This technology groups and routes shipments in a smart way, providing more fluid and continuous movement of goods in the direction of the end customer with fewer hand-offs.
The CloudSort System is organized around a central REST API, that has predictable resource-oriented URLs, accepts JSON-encoded request bodies, returns JSON-encoded responses, and uses standard HTTP response codes, authentication, and verbs.
This documentation page contains relevant information about the CloudSort Systems architecture, integration processes and API references, as well as useful tips and guides to get started working and integrating with the CloudSort System.
 
 
Just getting started?
Checkout our development quickstart guide.
 
 
Need the API Specification?
Download the YAML or the JSON format of the API specification.
 
 
 

GuidesThe following sections walk you through common activities using the CloudSort API.

Development QuickstartThis section gets you up and running quickly with the CloudSort API and enables you to perform your first authenticated request against the System.
What you'll need

User Account: you need your email and password to authenticate with the API
A terminal: we use cURL in the examples, as well as jq to help us out a bit

Get authenticated
# let's define some globals that we'll use later on again
APIHOST="https://api.cloudsort.com"
EMAIL="myemail@corp.com"
PASSWORD="mypassword"

# get an authentication token
JWT=$(
curl -X POST "${APIHOST}/api/auth/login" -s \
    -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
    -H 'accept: application/json' \
    -d '{"email": "'$EMAIL'", "password": "'$PASSWORD'", "device_id": "web"}' | jq -r '.access'
)

Perform a request
Now that we have a token, we can perform requests against the API, like for example, load a list of shippers
curl -X GET "${APIHOST}/api/shippers/" -s \
    -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
    -H 'accept: application/json' \
    -H "Authorization: Bearer $JWT"

And that's it, happy integration! Please reach out to our support if you're running into problems or have any questions not covered by the documentation.
AuthenticationThe CloudSort API follows an exchange process to obtain industry standard RFC7519 compliant JSON Web Tokens (JWT). You need to have the following data available to authenticate with the system:

User E-Mail
User Password
Optional: Device ID, if not available use web

Please reach out to your Organization or Station Administrator to obtain credentials. If you are planning to use the API in the form of an operating tool to perform sortation and other tasks, please ensure you have a Device ID ready for authentication as well.
Obtaining a JWT
To obtain a JWT to authenticate subsequent requests, perform a login request:
curl -X POST "${APIHOST}/api/auth/login" \
    -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
    -H 'accept: application/json' \
    -d '{"email": "you@email.com", "password": "supersecret", "device_id": "web"}'

>>> {
    "refresh": "eyJ0eXAiOiJKV1QiLCJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiJ9.eyJ0b2tlbl90eXBlIjoicmVmcmVzaCIsImV4cCI6MTYyMjE5NjcxMiwianRpIjoiYTM3ZDg3MjA3MGExNDgyMGE5ZWViNjRkZjc2MThmNzciLCJ1c2VyX2lkIjoxMzUsInN1YiI6InN1cGVydXNlckBjbG91ZHNvcnQuY29tIiwiZnVsbF9uYW1lIjoiU3VwZXIgVXNlciIsImRldmljZV9pZCI6IndlYiJ9.F6bU1cXeBvjt_IWzALTt3-usUmqvql-Re7ZgJJzd6bo",
    "access": "eyJ0eXAiOiJKV1QiLCJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiJ9.eyJ0b2tlbl90eXBlIjoiYWNjZXNzIiwiZXhwIjoxNjIxOTgwNzEyLCJqdGkiOiJkMDk5ZGQ3ZTkxN2I0Mjg5ODI5MjM4ZmYwYjA0OTcwMCIsInVzZXJfaWQiOjEzNSwic3ViIjoic3VwZXJ1c2VyQGNsb3Vkc29ydC5jb20iLCJmdWxsX25hbWUiOiJTdXBlciBVc2VyIiwiZGV2aWNlX2lkIjoid2ViIn0.kDo5PbJfZr9gBtfXPzajZ_9FJoY9S78Am-3SaHk7KYk"
}

The value provided in the access property is the JWT to use for regular authentication. The refresh token is used to reauthenticate the client without prompting for a password, see refreshing authentication
Note: using the Device ID web will log the user in with "web app" capabilities. In order to log the user in with "operator" capabilities, replace the Device ID with the actual ID of the device to use.
Using a JWT
Once a login is performed, you can use the access token to authenticate regular requests to the API. For example to update your password, by setting the Authorization header in the request to the value Bearer <token>:
curl "${APIHOST}/api/packages/" \
    -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
    -H 'accept: application/json' \
    -H 'Authorization: Bearer eyJ0eXAiOiJKV1QiLCJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiJ9.eyJ0b2tlbl90eXBlIjoiYWNjZXNzIiwiZXhwIjoxNjIxOTgwNzEyLCJqdGkiOiJkMDk5ZGQ3ZTkxN2I0Mjg5ODI5MjM4ZmYwYjA0OTcwMCIsInVzZXJfaWQiOjEzNSwic3ViIjoic3VwZXJ1c2VyQGNsb3Vkc29ydC5jb20iLCJmdWxsX25hbWUiOiJTdXBlciBVc2VyIiwiZGV2aWNlX2lkIjoid2ViIn0.kDo5PbJfZr9gBtfXPzajZ_9FJoY9S78Am-3SaHk7KYk'

>>> {
    ...,
    "results": [...]
}

If the token is expired, or invalid, the API responds with a 401 error, without specifying what is wrong. Try to reauthenticate and obtain a new token, or investigate the current token's expiration by decoding it.
Refreshing a JWT
To refresh an expired access JWT and authenticate subsequent requests, perform a refresh request:
curl -X POST "${APIHOST}/api/auth/refresh" \
    -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
    -H 'accept: application/json' \
    -d '{"refresh": "eyJ0eXAiOiJKV1QiLCJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiJ9.eyJ0b2tlbl90eXBlIjoicmVmcmVzaCIsImV4cCI6MTYyMjE5NjcxMiwianRpIjoiYTM3ZDg3MjA3MGExNDgyMGE5ZWViNjRkZjc2MThmNzciLCJ1c2VyX2lkIjoxMzUsInN1YiI6InN1cGVydXNlckBjbG91ZHNvcnQuY29tIiwiZnVsbF9uYW1lIjoiU3VwZXIgVXNlciIsImRldmljZV9    pZCI6IndlYiJ9.F6bU1cXeBvjt_IWzALTt3-usUmqvql-Re7ZgJJzd6bo"}'

>>> {
    "refresh": "eyJ0eXAiOiJKV1QiLCJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiJ9.eyJ0b2tlbl90eXBlIjoicmVmcmVzaCIsImV4cCI6MTYyMjE5NjcxMiwianRpIjoiYTM3ZDg3MjA3MGExNDgyMGE5ZWViNjRkZjc2MThmNzciLCJ1c2VyX2lkIjoxMzUsInN1YiI6InN1cGVydXNlckBjbG91ZHNvcnQuY29tIiwiZnVsbF9uYW1lIjoiU3VwZXIgVXNlciIsImRldmljZV9pZCI6IndlYiJ9.F6bU1cXeBvjt_IWzALTt3-usUmqvql-Re7ZgJJzd6bo",
    "access": "eyJ0eXAiOiJKV1QiLCJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiJ9.eyJ0b2tlbl90eXBlIjoiYWNjZXNzIiwiZXhwIjoxNjIxOTgwNzEyLCJqdGkiOiJkMDk5ZGQ3ZTkxN2I0Mjg5ODI5MjM4ZmYwYjA0OTcwMCIsInVzZXJfaWQiOjEzNSwic3ViIjoic3VwZXJ1c2VyQGNsb3Vkc29ydC5jb20iLCJmdWxsX25hbWUiOiJTdXBlciBVc2VyIiwiZGV2aWNlX2lkIjoid2ViIn0.kDo5PbJfZr9gBtfXPzajZ_9FJoY9S78Am-3SaHk7KYk"
}

You receive a new access and refresh token. Use the access token to authenticate regular requests and keep the refresh token for the next time you need to refresh the access token.
ManifestingThe CloudSort system includes a set of features used to communicate information about packages and containers that are entering or exiting the system. This capability is an important aspect of integrating with upstream and downstream carriers, customers and business partners.
 
Any organization tendering packages or containers to a facility using CloudSort software needs to provide the agreed upon package level detail in the form of an Inbound Manifest. The Inbound Manifest enables the facility to sort the shipments in the most effective manner. Failing to provide an Inbound Manifest before a CloudSort-enabled facility receives the packages and containers can result in delays because potentially critical information is missing1. There are two categories used when tendering packages to the system:

Labeled Packages: packages tendered to CloudSort that are registered and labeled for final mile delivery. CloudSort provides sortation and middle mile services.
Unlabeled Packages: packages tendered to CloudSort that are not registered or labeled. CloudSort registers and labels packages for final mile delivery, in addition to providing, sortation and middle mile services.

Upstream integrations like this can obtain periodic extracts of the processed packages via the packages API using reporting specific filters.
 
1 Some packages may be processable without a prior inbound manifest, please refer to your support contact for more details.
Inbound: Labeled Packages
Labeled packages are communicated in bulk to the CloudSort system via the inbound manifest endpoint. You need the following data to proceed with the process:

A valid JWT authentication (see Authentication)
A valid Entry Station ID indicating where the packages & containers are to be tendered to
Optional: a valid Carrier name indicating the final mile carrier of the package (see Carrier API)
Optional: the unit for weight (lbs, ounces or g) and for dimensions (in or cm). By default, its pounds and inches.

Limitations: The Inbound Manifest API is limited to 2500 packages per request. For larger manifests, please consider splitting them into separate requests and using the external_id to keep a shared reference. Alternatively, please reach out to your support contact for more information.
To send an inbound manifest to CloudSort, perform a request as follows:
APIHOST="https://api.cloudsort.com"
TOKEN=...
curl -X POST "${APIHOST}/api/manifests/inbound/" \
    -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
    -H 'accept: application/json' \
    -H "Authorization: Bearer $TOKEN" \
    -d '{
        "packages": [
            {
                "tracking_number": "TRACKNUM#P1",
                "container_tracking_number": "TRACKNUM#C1",
                "load_name": "TRACKNUM#L1",
                "entry_station": <Entry Station ID>,
                "carrier": <Carrier Name> (e.g "USPS"),
                "destination_full_name": "Winnifred Corrado",
                "destination_address": "479 STATE HWY O",
                "destination_city": "KISSEE MILLS",
                "destination_state": "MO",
                "destination_country": "USA",
                "destination_zipcode": "12112",
                "length": 10.19,
                "width": 3.48,
                "height": 2.43,
                "dim_unit": "in",
                "weight": 5.91,
                "weight_unit": "lbs"
            },
            {
                "tracking_number": "TRACKNUM#P2",
                "container_tracking_number": "TRACKNUM#C2",
                "load_name": "TRACKNUM#L1",
                "entry_station": <Entry Station ID>,
                "carrier": <Carrier Name> (e.g "USPS"),
                "destination_full_name": "Max Burton",
                "destination_address": "2217 CLEARSPRING DR S",
                "destination_city": "IRVING",
                "destination_state": "TX",
                "destination_country": "USA",
                "destination_zipcode": "750633358",
                "length": 9.21,
                "width": 5.51,
                "height": 8.10,
                "dim_unit": "in",
                "weight": 2.37,
                "weight_unit": "lbs"
            },
            {
                "tracking_number": "TRACKNUM#P3",
                "entry_station": <Entry Station ID>,
                "carrier": <Carrier Name> (e.g "USPS"),

>>> {
  "id": <ID>,
  "status": "ACCEPTED",
  ...,
  "issues": []
}

The System response to an inbound manifest indicates whether the manifest has been accepted or not. It also provides a list of issues, being either of level=error, or level=warning. Error-level packages are not accepted into the system and have to be corrected and manifested again. Warning-level packages are accepted into the system, but may be incorrectly processed because of the returned issues. To correct a previously manifested package, simply perform another inbound manifest request with the corrected data. The packages in the system are updated to the provided, new information.
Note that there are alternative ways of ingesting these inbound manifests, such as via SFTP and custom file formats. Please reach out to your support contact for details.
Custom Integrations and Special Flags
The package and container objects in the inbound manifest can be modified with a variety of special flags, and values relating to custom integrations. This section outlines which are available and how they should be used, please note that these are only active if previously agreed. Please reach out to your support contact to arrange use of these values.

com.cloudsort.integrations.general.passthroughbol: Enable a "Passthrough BOL" for packages (can be specified on package level, can be specified on container level and will be propagated to all packages of the given container) that will be used to pre-define the BOL on outbound containers. Usage: {"packages": [{..., "labels": {"com.cloudsort.integrations.general.passthroughbol": "<value>"}}, ...], ...}.

com.cloudsort.integrations.general.passthroughawb: Enable a "Passthrough AWB" for packages (can be specified on package level, can be specified on container level and will be propagated to all packages of the given container) that will be used to pre-define the AWB on outbound containers. Usage: {"packages": [{..., "labels": {"com.cloudsort.integrations.general.passthroughawb": "<value>"}}, ...], ...}.


Inbound: Unlabeled Packages
Leveraging CloudSorts carrier integrations, it is possible to register and generate packages for delivery through the CloudSort system. The Package Create API provides everything needed to prepare an item for shipping. You need the following to proceed:

A valid JWT authentication (see Authentication)
A valid Entry Station ID indicating where the package is tendered to
A valid Carrier ID indicating the final mile carrier of the package (see Carrier API)

To create a package and obtain label data from CloudSort, perform a request as follows:
APIHOST="https://api.cloudsort.com"
TOKEN=...
curl -X POST "${APIHOST}/api/packages/" \
    -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
    -H 'accept: application/json' \
    -H "Authorization: Bearer $TOKEN" \
    -d '{
           "station": <Entry Station ID>,
           "carrier": <Carrier ID>,
           "consignee_full_name": "Winnifred Corrado",
           "consignee_address": "479 State Hwy O",
           "consignee_address_city": "Kissee Mills",
           "consignee_address_state": "MO",
           "zipcode": "12112",
           "size_l": 10.19,
           "size_w": 3.48,
           "size_h": 2.43,
           "weight": 5.91
        }'

>>> {
  "id": <ID>,
  "tracking_number": <Newly Issued Tracking Number>
  "label_zpl": {
      "data": "^XA...^XZ",
      "content_type": "x-application/zpl"
  },
  ...
}

The API accepts package data, such as dimensions, destination etc, and generates a tracking number, label data and auxiliary information using the specified Carrier ID. Once labeled with the provided ZPL layout, the package is tendered to the CloudSort Facility.
Outbound
Outbound Manifests are transmitted to downstream organizations in accordance with agreed upon timelines, generally when the CloudSort Facility dispatches packages and containers.. Similar to the Inbound Manifest, the Outbound Manifest includes package level detail needed by the downstream organization to enable packages to be processed. Packages and containers are typically dispatched on outbound loads that follow a route, and delivered to one or more stops. For each stop the System generates and transmits an Outbound Manifest according to the rules and integration implemented for the owning carrier. The system is capable of generating custom formats and using arbitrary communication protocols for each downstream integration. If no specific integration exists, the system will not transmit any information.The respective carrier or business partner is able to retrieve dispatched package information via the reporting capabilities.

Overview
Callback Authentication

WebHook Payloads

Overview
The CloudSort System provides an event stream via a webhook-system. Webhooks are managed through subscriptions that the CloudSort System uses to forward relevant data to. As such, a consumer of a webhook subscription will need to have an active web service available that can receive POST or PUT requests containing the relevant data as payloads. For more details on webhooks see Wikipedia.
A user can subscribe to the webhooks using the Management API. Using the APIs, a user can define what HTTP-method should be used and what URL a webhook event should be posted to. Furthermore, the API allows to select certain filters to only receive relevant updates.
To manage create a new webhook subscription, all that is needed is
APIHOST="https://api.cloudsort.com"
TOKEN=...
curl -X POST "${APIHOST}/api/webhooks/" \
    -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
    -H 'accept: application/json' \
    -H "Authorization: Bearer $TOKEN" \
    -d '{
           "url": <URL of Receiver Endpoint>,
           "method": <POST|PUT>,
           "filter_events": []
        }'

>>> {
  "id": <ID>,
  ...
}

The above will create a default subscription for relevant TRACKING_UPDATES of PACKAGE resources for the specified receiver and will provided the updates according to the users permissions.
Callback Authentication
The receiver endpoint of the webhook subscription is expected to manage authentication and origin validation via the receiver URL transparently to the CloudSort system. The susbcriber has therefore two main options to establish a trusted origin:

API Token Authentication (recommended)
Basic Authentication

Note that for either of the authentication methods, it is imperative that the receiver endpoint uses SSL-encryption (HTTPS) to secure the connection.
API Token Authentication
One of the simplest and easiest to manage authentication methods is using API tokens. The receiver system issues a token (this can be a JWT, or e.g. a cryptographically generated random string) and the receiver endpoint expects that the request sent to it, is executed with a URL query parameter specifying that key. The receiver endpoint then validates the key and if it's a trusted key, allows the processing of the payload, otherwise rejects it. All that is required on the subscription to the WebHooks is that the URL defined in the subscription payload, includes that query parameter and API token.
Consider the following example system:
Server A has an endpoint https://server-a.com/receive-webhooks. That endpoint expects a query parameter api-token. Server A also has a tool that can generate tokens, that the receive-webhooks endpoint is able to validate. The system administrator of Server A will now perform the following steps:

Generate an API token with Server A
Create a subscription with CloudSorts WebHook system using as the URL https://server-a.com/receive-webhooks?api-token=<token from 1 here>

When the CloudSort system sends a WebHook payload to the URL - which has the query parameter configured - Server A can validate that API token and reject any request that is using an invalid, destroyed or non-existent token.
Basic Authentication
An alternative to the API Token authetnication is using HTTP Basic Authentication. The receiver system issues a user and password and the receiver endpoint expects that the request sent to it, is executed with the Authorization: Basic ... header. The receiver endpoint then validates the user and password and if it's a trusted user/password, allows the processing of the payload, otherwise rejects it. All that is required on the subscription to the WebHooks is that the URL defined in the subscription payload, includes that user/password data as part of the authentication spec: https://user:pass@example.com/receive-webhooks.
Consider the following example system:
Server A has an endpoint https://server-a.com/receive-webhooks. That endpoint expects a basic auth header. Server A also has a tool that can generate users and passwords, that the receive-webhooks endpoint is able to validate. The system administrator of Server A will now perform the following steps:

Generate an user and password with Server A
Create a subscription with CloudSorts WebHook system using as the URL https://<user>:<password>@server-a.com/receive-webhooks

When the CloudSort system sends a WebHook payload to the URL, it will parse the authentication section (before the @) into a Basic Authentication header and attach it to the request. Server A can validate that header and reject any request that is using an invalid, destroyed or non-existent users and passwords.
Advanced Usage
More advanced usage of the WebHooks is available, to allow the use of different protocols for consumer targets, as well as modify format and deal with exceptions. The following advanced configurations are available:
Non-HTTP Targets
The examples in this guide assume the use of an HTTP(s) endpoint that receives the WebHook events. The CloudSort system provides alternative protocols of communication to facilitate connectivity with different systems. At the moment, the following protocols are supported:

http(s)
(s)ftp

To switch a WebHook Subscription from e.g. HTTPS to SFTP, all that's necessary is to change the url property of the subscription payload to follow the following pattern: sftp://<username>:<password>@<sftp-host>:<port>/path/to/upload/to. The system will automatically write files into the given directory containing the payloads of the WebHook Events. It is possible to customize the filenames the system generates, for more information and guidance regarding that, please reach out to your support contact.
Non-JSON Format
The system also allows to modify the format in which the WebHooks are sending payloads. The following formats are available:

JSON (default)
CSV

It is important to note, that the CSV format is only provided as a legacy tool, and does not contain the full depth of data as e.g. the JSON format due to limitations of the CSV data layout. Some formats can additionally be customized with specific dialects, e.g. a custom set of CSV header names, to make use of this feature, please reach out to your support contact.
WebHooks State & History
The WebHooks system provides additional tools to ease the development and troubleshooting process while integrating, or facing availability issues. Each WebHook subscription can be explicitly disabled via the disabled boolean flag that can be used in the PATCH API endpoint. A disabled subscription will still generate the payloads, and only stop communicating them to the target system. This gives the target system time to recover, or modify the integration, without loosing any events. Once the target system is ready to receive the webhooks, they can be replayed.
Each subscription provides a "History" API endpoint, that allows the retrieval and inspection of past executions of the webhook. The history data for a WebHook subscription will expose a task_id that can be used to replay the given event at any time.
Replaying WebHooks
WebHook events can be replayed in two ways - both actions are executed via the same Task API Resubmit Endpoint:

Specific list of events
Time-range of events

In order to re-transmit a single, or list of specific WebHook event, collect the task_id values from the History API available on the WebHooks API and use the following payload. Please note that using the all parameter is needed if some or all of the events have been marked as a successful initial transmission. The resubmit API will otherwise ignore already succeeded events and filter the provided list of IDs to only failed/pending events.
{
  "all": true,
  "task_ids": [<id1>, <id2>, ...]
}

To re-transmit an entire range of tasks, collect the object_id and object_type_id information from the WebHooks API via the task_object_summary property of the details response. Using the following payload will re-transmit an entire time range. Again, using all is encouraged if the actual execution state of the events should be ignored. If not provided, or false, the system will only re-transmit the failed/pending events.
{
  "all": true,
  "object_id": <id>,
  "object_type_id": <type id>,
  "from_date": "YYYY-MM-DDTHH-mm-ssZ",
  "to_date": "YYYY-MM-DDTHH-mm-ssZ"
}

WebHook events are not replayed through the main-line queues, but through a secondary system. This secondary system is throttled to prevent overloads on the CloudSort system, as well as on the target system. Please reach out to your support contact for more details on expected delivery times of large volume re-transmissions.
Automatically Disabled WebHooks
The system has a protective mechanism in which it will automatically disable faulty WebHook Subscriptions. The decision to disable a subscription is based on the volume of events and a failure rate calculated over a rolling window. If a WebHook gets disabled automatically, the subscriber will be notified via the emails provided in the notification_emails list when setting up the subscription.
It is important to note that while a WebHook is disabled, no payloads are lost. The system simply stops communicating with the target. Once the WebHook is re-enabled, the previous unsent payloads can be manually re-transmitted. Please review the "Replaying WebHooks" section or reach out to your support contact for more information.
Subscription Examples
To susbcribe to different WebHook events, see belows examples.
Tracking Updates: All Resources
The following will create a subscription for all tracking updates for all resources
APIHOST="https://api.cloudsort.com"
TOKEN=...
curl -X POST "${APIHOST}/api/webhooks/" \
    -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
    -H 'accept: application/json' \
    -H "Authorization: Bearer $TOKEN" \
    -d '{
           "url": <URL of Receiver Endpoint>,
           "method": <POST|PUT>,
           "filter_events": [
              {
                "filter_type": "TRACKING_UPDATE",
                "resource_type": "*",
                "event_types": []
              }
           ]
        }'

>>> {
  "id": <ID>,
  ...
}

Tracking Updates: Containers only
The following will create a subscription for all tracking updates for containers
APIHOST="https://api.cloudsort.com"
TOKEN=...
curl -X POST "${APIHOST}/api/webhooks/" \
    -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
    -H 'accept: application/json' \
    -H "Authorization: Bearer $TOKEN" \
    -d '{
           "url": <URL of Receiver Endpoint>,
           "method": <POST|PUT>,
           "filter_events": [
              {
                "filter_type": "TRACKING_UPDATE",
                "resource_type": "CONTAINER",
                "event_types": []
              }
           ]
        }'

>>> {
  "id": <ID>,
  ...
}

Tracking Updates: Packages only
The following will create a subscription for all tracking updates for packages
APIHOST="https://api.cloudsort.com"
TOKEN=...
curl -X POST "${APIHOST}/api/webhooks/" \
    -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
    -H 'accept: application/json' \
    -H "Authorization: Bearer $TOKEN" \
    -d '{
           "url": <URL of Receiver Endpoint>,
           "method": <POST|PUT>,
           "filter_events": [
              {
                "filter_type": "TRACKING_UPDATE",
                "resource_type": "PACKAGE",
                "event_types": []
              }
           ]
        }'

>>> {
  "id": <ID>,
  ...
}

Tracking Updates: Packages, arrived only
The following will create a subscription for all "arrived" tracking updates for packages
APIHOST="https://api.cloudsort.com"
TOKEN=...
curl -X POST "${APIHOST}/api/webhooks/" \
    -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
    -H 'accept: application/json' \
    -H "Authorization: Bearer $TOKEN" \
    -d '{
           "url": <URL of Receiver Endpoint>,
           "method": <POST|PUT>,
           "filter_events": [
              {
                "filter_type": "TRACKING_UPDATE",
                "resource_type": "PACKAGE",
                "event_types": ["ARRIVED"]
              }
           ]
        }'

>>> {
  "id": <ID>,
  ...
}

Outbound Manifests: All
The following will create a subscription for all outbound manifests
APIHOST="https://api.cloudsort.com"
TOKEN=...
curl -X POST "${APIHOST}/api/webhooks/" \
    -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
    -H 'accept: application/json' \
    -H "Authorization: Bearer $TOKEN" \
    -d '{
           "url": <URL of Receiver Endpoint>,
           "method": <POST|PUT>,
           "filter_events": [
              {
                "filter_type": "OUTBOUND_MANIFEST",
                "resource_type": "*"
              }
           ]
        }'

>>> {
  "id": <ID>,
  ...
}

Outbound Manifests: Containers
The following will create a subscription for all outbound manifests including only container resources
APIHOST="https://api.cloudsort.com"
TOKEN=...
curl -X POST "${APIHOST}/api/webhooks/" \
    -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
    -H 'accept: application/json' \
    -H "Authorization: Bearer $TOKEN" \
    -d '{
           "url": <URL of Receiver Endpoint>,
           "method": <POST|PUT>,
           "filter_events": [
              {
                "filter_type": "OUTBOUND_MANIFEST",
                "resource_type": "CONTAINER"
              }
           ]
        }'

>>> {
  "id": <ID>,
  ...
}

Outbound Manifests: Packages
The following will create a subscription for all outbound manifests including only package resources
APIHOST="https://api.cloudsort.com"
TOKEN=...
curl -X POST "${APIHOST}/api/webhooks/" \
    -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
    -H 'accept: application/json' \
    -H "Authorization: Bearer $TOKEN" \
    -d '{
           "url": <URL of Receiver Endpoint>,
           "method": <POST|PUT>,
           "filter_events": [
              {
                "filter_type": "OUTBOUND_MANIFEST",
                "resource_type": "PACKAGE"
              }
           ]
        }'

>>> {
  "id": <ID>,
  ...
}

Webhook Payloads
The following extract outlines the schema used by the webhook system. The data a subscriber will receive is of type
WebHookEvent.
Payload Sizes

TRACKING_UPDATE: tracking update payloads typically range from 1kb - 10kb (larger payloads might be received!). The size depedends on the number of events registered for the given resource.
OUTBOUND_MANIFEST: outbound manifest payloads can become relatively large. The expected size is around 1mb per 1000 packages. Clients should ensure that according to their expectations, larger payloads are handled correctly.

definitions:

  # The main WebHook Event Structure - this is the container for all WebHook payloads
  # and according to the `type`, the `payload` will vary.
  WebHookEvent:
    title: Web Hook Event
    type: object
    properties:
      id:
        description: The ID of the webhook event.
        type: string
        format: uuid4
      timestamp:
        description: The time the web hook event was first sent.
        type: string
        format: date-time
      type:
        description: The type of webhook event. This will inform the schema of the `payload` property.
        type: string
        enum:
        - TRACKING_UPDATE
        - OUTBOUND_MANIFEST
      payload:
        description: The list of event payloads, e.g. TrackingUpdatePayload, or OutboundManifestPayload.
        type: object

  # Payload for `TRACKING_UPDATE` WebHooks
  TrackingUpdatePayload:
    title: Tracking Update Payload
    description: |

      The payload for webhook events of type `TRACKING_UPDATE` will contain
      a reference to the resource that was updated (e.g. a package), and what
      the updated event was.

      Refer to the `event` property to understand what triggered the webhook event,
      refer to the `event_history` property to see all `events` triggered so far for
      the given package or container.
    type: object
    properties:
      resource:
        description: The resource type for which the event was registered.
        type: string
        enum:
        - PACKAGE
        - CONTAINER
      id:
        description: The system internal ID of the resource for which the event was registered.
        type: integer
      tracking_number:
        description: The tracking number of the resource for which the event was registered.
        type: string
      tracking_number_alias:
        description: The human readable alias of the tracking number of the resource for which the event was registered.
        type: string
      original_tracking_number:
        description: The original tracking number of the resource in case it has been relabeled.
        type: string
      external_tracking_number:
        description: The shipper/customer-specific tracking number of the resource for which the event was registered.
        type: string
      owner_id:
        description: The customer ID owning the resource.
        type: integer
      owner_name:
        description: The customer name owning the resource.
        type: string
      shipper_id:
        description: The shipper ID responsible for the resource upstream of the customer.
        type: integer
      shipper_name:
        description: The shipper name responsible for the resource upstream of the customer.
        type: string
      carrier_id:
        description: The carrier ID of the resource.
        type: integer
      carrier_name:
        description: The carrier name of the resource.
        type: string
      awb:
        description: The AWB assigned to the resource.
        type: string
      bol:
        description: The bol assigned to the resource.
        type: string
      labels:
        description: The labels assigned to the resource
        type: object
        additionalProperties:
          type: string

      contained_resources:
        type: array
        items:
          "$ref": "#/definitions/ContainedResource"
      event:
        "$ref": "#/definitions/TrackingEvent"
      event_history:
        type: array
        items:
          "$ref": "#/definitions/TrackingEvent"
  ContainedResource:
    title: Contained Resource
    description: A resource contained in the parent.
    type: object
    properties:
      resource:
        description: The resource type described by this object.
        type: string
        enum:
        - PACKAGE
        - CONTAINER
      id:
        description: The system internal ID of the resource.
        type: integer
      tracking_number:
        description: The tracking number of the resource.
        type: string
      tracking_number_alias:
        description: The human readable alias of the tracking number of the resource.
        type: string
      original_tracking_number:
        description: The original tracking number of the resource in case it has been relabeled.
        type: string
      external_tracking_number:
        description: The shipper/customer-specific tracking number of the resource.
        type: string
  TrackingEvent:
    title: Tracking Event
    description: A tracking event for a resource.
    type: object
    properties:
      timestamp:
        description: The time the event was registered.
        type: string
        format: date-time
      event_type:
        description: The type of tracking event registered.
        type: string
        enum:
        - MANIFESTED_INBOUND
        - ARRIVED
        - SCANNED
        - PRIMARY
        - SECONDARY
        - ZONE
        - CONTAINERIZED
        - STAGED
        - LOADED
        - DISPATCHED
        - MANIFESTED_OUTBOUND
        - CARRIER_ARRIVED_AT_FACILITY
        - CARRIER_IN_TRANSIT
        - CARRIER_OUT_FOR_DELIVERY
        - CARRIER_DELIVERED
        - CARRIER_DELIVERY_FAILED
      event_location:
        "$ref": "#/definitions/EventLocation"
      station_id:
        description: The station ID at which the event was registered.
        type: integer
      station_name:
        description: The station name at which the event was registered.
        type: string
  EventLocation:
    title: Event Location
    description: The location of a tracking event (provided when available).
    In-station events have the station's location, while events that take place
    outside of the station will have the specific location where the event was
    triggered. For MANIFESTED_INBOUND events the location is where the data is
    manifested to and for MANIFESTED_OUTBOUND events the location is where the
    data is manifested from.
    type: object
    properties:
      latitude:
        description: The latitude of the location.
        type: float
      longitude:
        description: The longitude of the location.
        type: float
      address:
        description: The address of the location.
        type: string
      city:
        description: The city of the location.
        type: string
      state:
        description: The state of the location.
        type: string
      zipcode:
        description: The zipcode of the location.
        type: string
      country:
        description: The country of the location.
        type: string

  # Payload for `OUTBOUND_MANIFEST` WebHooks
  OutboundManifestPayload:
    title: Outbound Manifest Payload
    description: |

      The payload for webhook events of type `OUTBOUND_MANIFEST` will contain
      a reference to the load that was dispatched, the station it originated from,
            as well as which packages and containers have been dispatched.
    type: object
    properties:
      id:
        description: The system internal ID of the dispatched load.
        type: integer
      name:
        description: The human readable name of the dispatched load.
        type: string
      station_id:
        description: The ID of the station of the dispatched load.
        type: integer
      station_name:
        description: The human readable name of the station of the dispatched load.
        type: string
      trailer_id:
        description: The trailer ID of the dispatched load.
        type: string
      dispatched_timestamp:
        description: The time the load was dispatched.
        type: string
        format: date-time
      containers:
                type: array
                items:
                    "$ref": "#/definitions/OutboundManifestContainer"
      packages:
                type: array
                items:
                    "$ref": "#/definitions/OutboundManifestPackage"
    OutboundManifestContainer:
        title: "Outbound Manifest Resource: Container"
        description: |

            The detail-level data of the resource that was dispatched with the given
            load.
        type: object
    properties:
            id:
        description: The system internal ID of the resource.
        type: integer
      tracking_number:
        description: The tracking number of the resource.
        type: string
      bol:
        description: The BOL assigned to the resource.
        type: string
      awb:
        description: The AWB assigned to the resource.
        type: string
      target_stop:
        description: The stop name targetted by the resource.
        type: string
      target_stop_id:
        description: The internal ID of the stop targetted by the resource.
        type: integer
      container_type:
        description: The type of the container.
        type: string
        enum: ["BOX", "GAYLORD", "BAG", "PALLET", "EH"]
      labels:
        description: The labels assigned to the resource
        type: object
        additionalProperties:
          type: string
    OutboundManifestPackage:
        title: "Outbound Manifest Resource: Package"
        description: |

            The detail-level data of the package that was dispatched with the given
            load.
        type: object
    properties:
            id:
        description: The system internal ID of the resource.
        type: integer
      tracking_number:
        description: The tracking number of the resource.
        type: string
      tracking_number_alias:
        description: The human readable alias of the tracking number of the resource.
        type: string
      order_number:
        description: The order number assigned to the package.
        type: string
      bol:
        description: The BOL assigned to the container if the package has been containerised.
        type: string
      awb:
        description: The AWB assigned to the container if the package has been containerised.
        type: string
      target_stop:
        description: The stop name targetted by the resource.
        type: string
      target_stop_id:
        description: The internal ID of the stop targetted by the resource.
        type: integer
      original_tracking_number:
        description: The original tracking number of the resource in case it has been relabeled.
        type: string
      external_tracking_number:
        description: The shipper/customer-specific tracking number of the resource.
        type: string
      container_tracking_number:
        description: The container tracking number if the package has been containerised.
        type: string
      container_id:
        description: The container ID if the package has been containerised.
        type: integer
      container_type:
        description: The type of the container if the package has been containerised.
        type: string
        enum: ["BOX", "GAYLOAD", "BAG", "PALLET"]
      parent_container_id:
        description: The parent container ID if the packages container has been grouped.
        type: integer
      owner_id:
        description: The customer ID owning the resource.
        type: integer
      owner_name:
        description: The customer name owning the resource.
        type: string
      shipper_id:
        description: The shipper ID responsible for the resource upstream of the customer.
        type: integer
      shipper_name:
        description: The shipper name responsible for the resource upstream of the customer.
        type: string
      shipper_station_name:
        description: The name of the shippers station from where the package was received by the customer.
        type: string
      carrier_id:
        description: The carrier ID of the resource.
        type: integer
      carrier_name:
        description: The carrier name of the resource.
        type: string
      origin_station_id:
        description: The ID of the Customers station from where the package was sent to CloudSort.
        type: int
      origin_station_name:
        description: The name of the Customers station from where the package was sent to CloudSort.
        type: string
      created_timestamp:
        description: The timestamp at which the package was created in the CloudSort system.
        type: string
        format: date-time
      scanned_timestamp:
        description: The timestamp at which the package was first scanned in a CloudSort station.
        type: string
        format: date-time
      loaded_timestamp:
        description: The timestamp at which the package was loaded to the Outbound Load.
        type: string
        format: date-time
      consignee_address:
        description: The street component of the consignees address.
        type: string
      consignee_address_city:
        description: The city component of the consignees address.
        type: string
      consignee_address_country:
        description: The country component of the consignees address.
        type: string
      consignee_address_state:
        description: The state component of the consignees address.
        type: string
      consignee_zipcode:
        description: The zipcode component of the consignees address.
        type: string
      height:
        description: The height of the package, in inches.
        type: number
      length:
        description: The length of the package, in inches.
        type: number
      width:
        description: The width of the package, in inches.
        type: number
      weight:
        description: The weight of the package, in pounds.
        type: number
      sort_param:
        description: The sort parameter assigned to the package.
        type: string
      raw_barcode:
        description: The base64-encoded raw barcode data read from the package label.
        type: string
      labels:
        description: The labels assigned to the resource
        type: object
        additionalProperties:
          type: string

System InformationThe CloudSort System is a cloud-native service hosted by Google Cloud Platform (GCP). Sortation sites are connected via a centralized API that provides instructions to operator devices and administration tools. The API also interfaces with external organizations.
Cloud Platform and InfrastructureThe CloudSort System, from data and storage to API, is made available via dedicated resources leveraging Google Cloud Platform (GCP). As such, the system's components are provided in a highly scalable and resilient environment with high availability and low latency. It is replicated across multiple regions of the US territory to improve the operational speed and processing. Persisted data is regularly backed up and archived to ensure zero-loss and the possibility of tracing any customer or processing related issues arising during operations. Furthermore, using GCP enables the system to rely on state-of-the-art security, encryption and access protection for all resources and information entrusted to the components.
API LayerThe RESTful API provided by the system forms the core communication interface for any external and internal client. It follows and provides an openAPI V2 compliant format, that is available in the common JSON and YAML formats, as well as on a visual, interactive website hosted by the CloudSort System (access is provided with developer credentials).
Any access to the API or any component of the API service is secured with state-of-the-art SSL encryption, in combination with a set of access credentials. Furthermore, the access credentials are used to determine rights and permissions and limit access to resources and operations that the API exposes.
Access credentials (ie. user and password) for the API are not used directly, but follow an exchange process to obtain industry standard RFC7519 compliant JSON Web Tokens (JWT). Therefore to access an API endpoint, a client first goes through an authentication process with a username and password with the JWT endpoint to obtain an access token, and then requests the desired resource providing the token to the API via the HTTP authorization header.
The API itself is furthermore split into multiple sections, that are or not available for the given credentials. Depending on the user’s type (e.g. Customer, Carrier, or Internal/Staff) the API may restrict visibility and access to certain groups of resources, but always provides the endpoints necessary for the given use case.
Data and Storage LayerThe different kinds of data stored by the system, e.g. files, columnar-data, or image data, are managed by GCP provided services, which enable SSL encrypted communication and at rest encryption using the 256-bit Advanced Encryption Standard (AES-256).
Any access facilitated via the APIs, the operator device or the administrator tool requires a valid user to be active in the system. Users are created in a secure, dedicated part of the administrator tool. Within seconds a new operator is onboarded, a badge printed and sent to the shop floor without time consuming overhead.
 
 
 

Integrate with CloudSortIntegration with and use of the CloudSort System requires the following resources:

Internet-enabled (Ethernet, WiFi or LTE) PC, Laptop, or portable device with a chromium-based web browser (Google Chrome, Microsoft Edge) to access the administrator tools.

Internet-enabled (WiFi) LTE Zebra device (such as TC26 scanner) to be used by the operator.

Compatible printer to be coupled with the Zebra devices to print container and package labels on-site.

Management of the devices and operator tool is performed via Android Device Management (ADM) facilitating group-wide roll outs, configurations and maintenance of the devices.


Upstream and Downstream IntegrationsTo facilitate integrations with business partners, shippers and carriers, the CloudSort System is built on a pluggable, extensible infrastructure. This allows for the addition of custom modules as needed. Almost any data and communication requirements can be met within a short development cycle. Bi-directional data flow is supported, the system is equipped to either pull or push data from external entities, notify or receive notifications from third parties and aggregate or translate inbound and outbound data.
 
 
 

GlossaryResources and Terms
User: a person or machine, identified by a username, who utilizes the CloudSort system. Use of the Cloudsort APIs, operator tool or administrator tool, requires a valid user in the system.

Container: a virtual representation of the physical aggregation of packages into bags, pallets, Gaylords, etc. Containers result from the sortation process and are designed around destination, carrier or package characteristics. Container detail includes a unique identifier, package count, container weight and cubic volume.

Package: a virtual representation of physical packages with detailed information about customer, destination, shipper, carrier, mail classes, delivery times, weight and sizes.

Outbound Load: a collection of Packages and Containers that will be available at a Dock Door to be delivered on a Route.

Manifest: a mechanism used to transmit information about the physical aspects of the packages being tendered to CloudSort (Inbound Manifests), or being tendered by CloudSort to a downstream organization (Outbound Manifests). Manifests typically include package level detail such as size, weight, destination, classification, etc.

Tracking: a dedicated tracking event stream used to trace and store information about packages, such as location.

Labels: CloudSort provides printable labels for containers and packages. These are published as ZPL-code or image files.

Carrier: a Carrier is a company or a person legally entitled to transport goods. Usually, the Carrier works with Customers and Shippers to ship goods from one place to the other.


 
EventsThe following events are generated from processing a package through a CloudSort middle mile station and a downstream carrier. The order of events follows the expected lifecycle of a Package (though none of the steps is necessarily required and will depend on the individual CloudSort middle mile station operations).

MANIFESTED_INBOUND: A Customer transmitted an Inbound Manifest for the Package or Container.

ARRIVED: The Package has received an arrival scan at a CloudSort middle mile station.

SCANNED: Package or Container was scanned in CloudSort middle mile station.

PRIMARY: The Package or Container has been moved to Primary.

SECONDARY: The Package or Container has been moved to Secondary.

ZONE: The Package or Container has been processed to a Secondary Zone.

CONTAINERIZED: The Package has been placed inside a Container.

STAGED: The Package or Container is moved to a Staging area.

LOADED: The Package or Container is loaded into an Outbound Load.

DISPATCHED: The Package or Container has departed a CloudSort middle mile station in an Outbound Load.

MANIFESTED_OUTBOUND: The Package or Container has been manifested to the downstream Carrier (if integrated).

CARRIER_ARRIVED_AT_FACILITY: The Package or Container arrived to the a Carrier Station.

CARRIER_IN_TRANSIT: The Package or Container is in transit from a CloudSort middle mile station to a Carrier Station or between Carrier Stations.

CARRIER_OUT_FOR_DELIVERY: The Package is being delivered to the final destination by the Carrier.

CARRIER_DELIVERED: The Package was successfully delievered to the final destination by the Carrier.

CARRIER_DELIVERY_FAILED: The Package failed to be delievered to the final destination by the Carrier.


The remaining events generated by the system can be considered auxiliary data to the above events and are used for performance and quality control by the CloudSort middle mile stations.
 
 
 

Authentication APIThe following endpoints provide the means to authenticate, refresh and manage anything related to accessing the CloudSort System or APIs. See our Authentication Guide for more details.
Obtain JWT and Login This endpoint provides a JWT pair (access and refresh token) for
the provided user data. When logging in with a device_id different
from web, the endpoint initiates a session for the
operator, that is reflected in event and other related data.
This endpoint is used to sign-in via badge tokens, which are
available to be generated for each user in the system, permitting a
more operator-friendly sign-in process.
Access tokens are valid for 24h and refresh tokens for 72h.
It is possible to automatically obtain a new JWT pair via the
refresh endpoint within the
expiration period of the refresh token.
Request Body schema: application/jsonemailstring <email>  (Email)  The users email to authenticate with, optional if using the users badge token.
passwordrequiredstring (Password)   non-empty  The users password to authenticate with, or the users badge token.
device_idstring (Device id)   non-empty  Default:  "web" The device ID to assign to the session, use web for web-based activities, or leave empty.
Responses200 400 Invalid input.
413 Request payload too large.

system. Only device-based access should use the endpoint to signal

Inbound manifest Handler to receive an inbound manifest.
This API endpoint enables Users to create and address hold
reasons associated with a Package. When a list of hold
reasons is specified in the hold_for field, the CloudSort
system checks for their existence. If they don't already exist,
the system creates and assigns them to the specified Package.
Consequently, the Package can only be sorted after
resolving all the listed hold reasons.
Each time a new list of hold reasons is passed to the hold_for
field, the system marks any previously unresolved hold reasons
as resolved. If the hold_for field is left blank or not
included in the request, the system assumes all existing hold
reasons have been addressed and marks them as resolved.
In essence, this mechanism ensures that the Package's status
reflects the most recent list of hold reasons provided
via the hold_for field.

loadsArray of objects (NestedInboundManifestLoad)  The load declared on the Manifest. The name field can be used to link items of the packages and containers list via the load_name field.

In order to make the
request, the user needs to be:

Customer or Organization Staff in which the User will only have access to
the WebHook Subscriptions assigned and created by them.

The request will return the following data:

The id of the WebHook Subscription
The url to which the CloudSort System will notify if a certain event
got triggered. Supported protocols are HTTP, HTTPS, FTP and SFTP.
The method that the CloudSort System will use to do that request -
PUT or POST (only applies if protocol is HTTP or HTTPS)
The owner_id if the WebHook Subscription was created by a Customer
The organization_id if the WebHook Subscription was created by an
Organization Staff
The filter_events which indicates what should trigger the CloudSort
System to notify the Subscriber

The filter_events works as an array of objects that can have the
following fields:

filter_type, e.g. TRACKING_UPDATE or OUTBOUND_MANIFEST. To receive
all webhooks for all types of events, use *.
resource_type which defines which resource the Subscriber wants to be
notified of. Can be either PACKAGE or CONTAINER and if empty will
default to PACKAGE. To subscribe to all resource types, use *.
station_id which indicates the Station from where the Subscriber wants
to be notified. To subscribe to all stations, leave empty, or omit.

Depending on the filter_type the following additional filters are
as well available:

event_types - for TRACKING_UPDATE subscriptions - which defines what
Event types should make the CloudSort System notify the Subscriber about.
Use [] (empty list) to subscribe to all possible events, and omit the
parameter to subscribe to the default, most relevant set of events.

The disabled flag (also available on the PATCH endpoint) adds the ability
to pause/resume a Subscription temporarily. The system itself may act auto-
matically and disable a Subscription if it detects the target has become
unhealthy.

notification_emailsArray of strings[ items  non-empty  ] The emails to notify if the subscription gets automatically disabled due to health issues.
urlrequiredstring (Url)   non-empty  The target URL of the subscription. Use either http(s):// or (s)ftp:// protocols.

formatstring (Format)  Default:  "JSON" Enum: "JSON" "CSV"  Preview Feature: the format can be used to switch between consuming JSON or CSV. It is important to note that the CSV format comes with significantly reduced details. To get the full details for the WebHook Events, please use JSON format.

Resubmit Tasks Summary
This API allows to resubmit a given set of tasks via various options.
Each group of fields can be used distinctly, only one group of fields
can be used at a time.
Use the dry_run query parameter to simulate what would happen and
retrieve a Resubmission Response before actually submitting the list
of tasks.
Use the all field to re-submit all tasks, independent of their
execution state. If all is not true, then the resubmission will
only target tasks that have either failed, or not been executed at all.
Group 1 - Resubmission via Time-boundary and Object Reference
The fields labeled Group 1 are all required to be set when attempting
to resubmit a list of tasks based on a time range. The object ID and
object type ID references will be provided by the respective resource
API (e.g. WebHooks API).
Group 2 - Resubmission via Task IDs
The fields labeled Group 2 are all required to be set when attempting
to resubmit a list of tasks based on their IDs.
Authorizations:Bearerquery Parametersdry_runboolean Simulate the resubmission
Request Body schema: application/jsonallboolean (All)  Default:  false Include all tasks. By default the resubmission will not include all tasks, only the tasks in CREATED, or FAILED state. If all is set to True, all tasks, independent of their status will be resubmitted.
from_datestring <date-time>  (From date)  Group 1: The lower time boundary for the range of tasks to resubmit.
to_datestring <date-time>  (To date)  Group 1: The upper time boundary for the range of tasks to resubmit.
object_idinteger (Object id)  Group 1: The object ID for which to resubmit the tasks.
object_type_idinteger (Object type id)  Group 1: The object type ID for which to resubmit the tasks.
task_idsArray of integers Group 2: The list of task IDs to resubmit.
Responses200 Resubmission Details
400 Invalid input.
403 Authentication credentials were invalid, absent or insufficient.
413 Request payload too large.

IntroductionCLOUDSORT CORPORATION (“CloudSort”) is created for our e-commerce world.It provides “middle mile” software, sortation and transportation services that are designed from the ground up to serve e-commerce.Core to the CloudSort proposition is a cloud-based sortation software platform (“CloudSort System”).This technology groups and routes shipments in a smart way, providing more fluid and continuous movement of goods in the direction of the end customer with fewer hand-offs.The CloudSort System is organized around a central REST API, that has predictable resource-oriented URLs, accepts JSON-encoded request bodies, returns JSON-encoded responses, and uses standard HTTP response codes, authentication, and verbs.This documentation page contains relevant information about the CloudSort Systems architecture, integration processes and API references, as well as useful tips and guides to get started working and integrating with the CloudSort System.Just getting started?Checkout our development quickstart guide.Need the API Specification?Download the YAML or the JSON format of the API specification.GuidesThe following sections walk you through common activities using the CloudSort API.Quickstart
Authentication
Manifesting
Webhooks

Development QuickstartThis section gets you up and running quickly with the CloudSort API and enables you to perform your first authenticated request against the System.What you'll need

User Account: you need your email and password to authenticate with the API
A terminal: we use cURL in the examples, as well as jq to help us out a bit

Get authenticated
# let's define some globals that we'll use later on again
APIHOST="https://api.cloudsort.com"
EMAIL="myemail@corp.com"
PASSWORD="mypassword"

# get an authentication token
JWT=$(
curl -X POST "${APIHOST}/api/auth/login" -s \
    -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
    -H 'accept: application/json' \
    -d '{"email": "'$EMAIL'", "password": "'$PASSWORD'", "device_id": "web"}' | jq -r '.access'
)

Perform a request
Now that we have a token, we can perform requests against the API, like for example, load a list of shippers
curl -X GET "${APIHOST}/api/shippers/" -s \
    -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
    -H 'accept: application/json' \
    -H "Authorization: Bearer $JWT"

And that's it, happy integration!Please reach out to our support if you're running into problems or have any questions not covered by the documentation.AuthenticationThe CloudSort API follows an exchange process to obtain industry standard RFC7519 compliant JSON Web Tokens (JWT).You need to have the following data available to authenticate with the system:

User E-Mail
User Password
Optional: Device ID, if not available use web

Please reach out to your Organization or Station Administrator to obtain credentials.If you are planning to use the API in the form of an operating tool to perform sortation and other tasks, please ensure you have a Device ID ready for authentication as well.Obtaining a JWT
To obtain a JWT to authenticate subsequent requests, perform a login request:
curl -X POST "${APIHOST}/api/auth/login" \
    -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
    -H 'accept: application/json' \
    -d '{"email": "you@email.com", "password": "supersecret", "device_id": "web"}'

The value provided in the access property is the JWT to use for regular authentication.The refresh token is used to reauthenticate the client without prompting for a password, see refreshing authentication
Note: using the Device ID web will log the user in with "web app" capabilities.In order to log the user in with "operator" capabilities, replace the Device ID with the actual ID of the device to use.Using a JWT
Once a login is performed, you can use the access token to authenticate regular requests to the API.For example to update your password, by setting the Authorization header in the request to the value Bearer <token>:
curl "${APIHOST}/api/packages/" \
    -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
    -H 'accept: application/json' \
    -H 'Authorization: Bearer eyJ0eXAiOiJKV1QiLCJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiJ9.eyJ0b2tlbl90eXBlIjoiYWNjZXNzIiwiZXhwIjoxNjIxOTgwNzEyLCJqdGkiOiJkMDk5ZGQ3ZTkxN2I0Mjg5ODI5MjM4ZmYwYjA0OTcwMCIsInVzZXJfaWQiOjEzNSwic3ViIjoic3VwZXJ1c2VyQGNsb3Vkc29ydC5jb20iLCJmdWxsX25hbWUiOiJTdXBlciBVc2VyIiwiZGV2aWNlX2lkIjoid2ViIn0.","textTemplate":"","metadataSeparator":"

You receive a new access and refresh token.Use the access token to authenticate regular requests and keep the refresh token for the next time you need to refresh the access token.ManifestingThe CloudSort system includes a set of features used to communicate information about packages and containers that are entering or exiting the system.This capability is an important aspect of integrating with upstream and downstream carriers, customers and business partners.Any organization tendering packages or containers to a facility using CloudSort software needs to provide the agreed upon package level detail in the form of an Inbound Manifest.The Inbound Manifest enables the facility to sort the shipments in the most effective manner.Failing to provide an Inbound Manifest before a CloudSort-enabled facility receives the packages and containers can result in delays because potentially critical information is missing1.There are two categories used when tendering packages to the system:

Labeled Packages: packages tendered to CloudSort that are registered and labeled for final mile delivery.CloudSort provides sortation and middle mile services.Unlabeled Packages: packages tendered to CloudSort that are not registered or labeled.CloudSort registers and labels packages for final mile delivery, in addition to providing, sortation and middle mile services.Upstream integrations like this can obtain periodic extracts of the processed packages via the packages API using reporting specific filters.1 Some packages may be processable without a prior inbound manifest, please refer to your support contact for more details.Inbound: Labeled Packages
Labeled packages are communicated in bulk to the CloudSort system via the inbound manifest endpoint.You need the following data to proceed with the process:

A valid JWT authentication (see Authentication)
A valid Entry Station ID indicating where the packages & containers are to be tendered to
Optional: a valid Carrier name indicating the final mile carrier of the package (see Carrier API)
Optional: the unit for weight (lbs, ounces or g) and for dimensions (in or cm).By default, its pounds and inches.Limitations: The Inbound Manifest API is limited to 2500 packages per request.For larger manifests, please consider splitting them into separate requests and using the external_id to keep a shared reference.Alternatively, please reach out to your support contact for more information.To send an inbound manifest to CloudSort, perform a request as follows:
APIHOST="https://api.cloudsort.com"
TOKEN=...curl -X POST "${APIHOST}/api/manifests/inbound/" \
    -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
    -H 'accept: application/json' \
    -H "Authorization: Bearer $TOKEN" \

The System response to an inbound manifest indicates whether the manifest has been accepted or not.It also provides a list of issues, being either of level=error, or level=warning.Error-level packages are not accepted into the system and have to be corrected and manifested again.Warning-level packages are accepted into the system, but may be incorrectly processed because of the returned issues.To correct a previously manifested package, simply perform another inbound manifest request with the corrected data.The packages in the system are updated to the provided, new information.Note that there are alternative ways of ingesting these inbound manifests, such as via SFTP and custom file formats.Please reach out to your support contact for details.Custom Integrations and Special Flags
The package and container objects in the inbound manifest can be modified with a variety of special flags, and values relating to custom integrations.This section outlines which are available and how they should be used, please note that these are only active if previously agreed.Please reach out to your support contact to arrange use of these values.com.cloudsort.integrations.general.passthroughbol: Enable a "Passthrough BOL" for packages (can be specified on package level, can be specified on container level and will be propagated to all packages of the given container) that will be used to pre-define the BOL on outbound containers.Usage: {"packages": [{..., "labels": {"com.cloudsort.integrations.general.passthroughbol": "<value>"}}, ...], ...}.com.cloudsort.integrations.general.passthroughawb: Enable a "Passthrough AWB" for packages (can be specified on package level, can be specified on container level and will be propagated to all packages of the given container) that will be used to pre-define the AWB on outbound containers.Usage: {"packages": [{..., "labels": {"com.cloudsort.integrations.general.passthroughawb": "<value>"}}, ...], ...}.Inbound: Unlabeled Packages
Leveraging CloudSorts carrier integrations, it is possible to register and generate packages for delivery through the CloudSort system.The Package Create API provides everything needed to prepare an item for shipping.You need the following to proceed:

A valid JWT authentication (see Authentication)
A valid Entry Station ID indicating where the package is tendered to
A valid Carrier ID indicating the final mile carrier of the package (see Carrier API)

To create a package and obtain label data from CloudSort, perform a request as follows:

Leveraging CloudSorts carrier integrations, it is possible to register and generate packages for delivery through the CloudSort system.The Package Create API provides everything needed to prepare an item for shipping.You need the following to proceed:

A valid JWT authentication (see Authentication)
A valid Entry Station ID indicating where the package is tendered to
A valid Carrier ID indicating the final mile carrier of the package (see Carrier API)

To create a package and obtain label data from CloudSort, perform a request as follows:
APIHOST="https://api.cloudsort.com"
TOKEN=...curl -X POST "${APIHOST}/api/packages/" \
    -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
    -H 'accept: application/json' \
    -H "Authorization: Bearer $TOKEN" \
    -d '{
           "station": <Entry Station ID>,
           "carrier": <Carrier ID>,
           "consignee_full_name": "Winnifred Corrado",
           "consignee_address": "479 State Hwy O",
           "consignee_address_city": "Kissee Mills",
           "consignee_address_state": "MO",
           "zipcode": "12112",
           "size_l": 10.19,
           "size_w": 3.48,
           "size_h": 2.43,
           "weight": 5.91
        }'

>>> {
  "id": <ID>,
  "tracking_number": <Newly Issued Tracking Number>
  "label_zpl": {
      "data": "^XA...^XZ",
      "content_type": "x-application/zpl"
  },
  ...}

The API accepts package data, such as dimensions, destination etc, and generates a tracking number, label data and auxiliary information using the specified Carrier ID.Once labeled with the provided ZPL layout, the package is tendered to the CloudSort Facility.Outbound
Outbound Manifests are transmitted to downstream organizations in accordance with agreed upon timelines, generally when the CloudSort Facility dispatches packages and containers..Similar to the Inbound Manifest, the Outbound Manifest includes package level detail needed by the downstream organization to enable packages to be processed.Packages and containers are typically dispatched on outbound loads that follow a route, and delivered to one or more stops.For each stop the System generates and transmits an Outbound Manifest according to the rules and integration implemented for the owning carrier.The system is capable of generating custom formats and using arbitrary communication protocols for each downstream integration.If no specific integration exists, the system will not transmit any information.The respective carrier or business partner is able to retrieve dispatched package information via the reporting capabilities.WebhooksContent

Overview
Callback Authentication
Advanced Usage
Subscription Examples
WebHook Payloads

Overview
The CloudSort System provides an event stream via a webhook-system.Webhooks are managed through subscriptions that the CloudSort System uses to forward relevant data to.As such, a consumer of a webhook subscription will need to have an active web service available that can receive POST or PUT requests containing the relevant data as payloads.For more details on webhooks see Wikipedia.A user can subscribe to the webhooks using the Management API.Using the APIs, a user can define what HTTP-method should be used and what URL a webhook event should be posted to.Furthermore, the API allows to select certain filters to only receive relevant updates.To manage create a new webhook subscription, all that is needed is
APIHOST="https://api.cloudsort.com"
TOKEN=...curl -X POST "${APIHOST}/api/webhooks/" \
    -H 'Content-Type: application/json' \
    -H 'accept: application/json' \
    -H "Authorization: Bearer $TOKEN" \
    -d '{
           "url": <URL of Receiver Endpoint>,
           "method": <POST|PUT>,
           "filter_events": []
        }'

>>> {
  "id": <ID>,
  ...}

The above will create a default subscription for relevant TRACKING_UPDATES of PACKAGE resources for the specified receiver and will provided the updates according to the users permissions.Callback Authentication
The receiver endpoint of the webhook subscription is expected to manage authentication and origin validation via the receiver URL transparently to the CloudSort system.The susbcriber has therefore two main options to establish a trusted origin:

API Token Authentication (recommended)
Basic Authentication

Note that for either of the authentication methods, it is imperative that the receiver endpoint uses SSL-encryption (HTTPS) to secure the connection.API Token Authentication

{"id_":"dad3ea54-1e07-4652-abf5-06e026ffd647","metadata":{"url":"https://api.cloudsort.com/api-docs"},"excludedEmbedMetadataKeys":[],"excludedLlmMetadataKeys":[],"relationships":{"SOURCE":{"nodeId":"551ed63b-9e02-487e-a57d-95f7fd46394e","metadata":{"url":"https://api.cloudsort.com/api-docs"},"hash":"zA1G6gtcDIM9+htSWo2CSQzS4EYHX071Eag1+DF2AJM="},"PREVIOUS":{"nodeId":"74d21d64-c404-45fa-ad48-ea25e6bdb0a2","metadata":{"url":"https://api.cloudsort.com/api-docs"},"hash":"M1N21iGQ4mO/UBKQOTQ9wFJkcObqyD/P89DY8c+Ynsk="},"NEXT":{"nodeId":"0eed35d0-0311-4c78-872b-9e1c707f73ee","metadata":{},"hash":"DA/PBvoavDD9SVgvA0CFpp+85fVG3jED2UcWZJib0jw="}},"text":"}

The above will create a default subscription for relevant TRACKING_UPDATES of PACKAGE resources for the specified receiver and will provided the updates according to the users permissions.Callback Authentication
The receiver endpoint of the webhook subscription is expected to manage authentication and origin validation via the receiver URL transparently to the CloudSort system.The susbcriber has therefore two main options to establish a trusted origin:

API Token Authentication (recommended)
Basic Authentication

Note that for either of the authentication methods, it is imperative that the receiver endpoint uses SSL-encryption (HTTPS) to secure the connection.API Token Authentication
One of the simplest and easiest to manage authentication methods is using API tokens.The receiver system issues a token (this can be a JWT, or e.g.a cryptographically generated random string) and the receiver endpoint expects that the request sent to it, is executed with a URL query parameter specifying that key.The receiver endpoint then validates the key and if it's a trusted key, allows the processing of the payload, otherwise rejects it.All that is required on the subscription to the WebHooks is that the URL defined in the subscription payload, includes that query parameter and API token.Consider the following example system:
Server A has an endpoint https://server-a.com/receive-webhooks. That endpoint expects a query parameter api-token.Server A also has a tool that can generate tokens, that the receive-webhooks endpoint is able to validate.The system administrator of Server A will now perform the following steps:

Generate an API token with Server A
Create a subscription with CloudSorts WebHook system using as the URL https://server-a.com/receive-webhooks?api-token=<token from 1 here>

When the CloudSort system sends a WebHook payload to the URL - which has the query parameter configured - Server A can validate that API token and reject any request that is using an invalid, destroyed or non-existent token.Basic Authentication
An alternative to the API Token authetnication is using HTTP Basic Authentication.The receiver system issues a user and password and the receiver endpoint expects that the request sent to it, is executed with the Authorization: Basic ...header.The receiver endpoint then validates the user and password and if it's a trusted user/password, allows the processing of the payload, otherwise rejects it.All that is required on the subscription to the WebHooks is that the URL defined in the subscription payload, includes that user/password data as part of the authentication spec: https://user:pass@example.com/receive-webhooks.
Consider the following example system:
Server A has an endpoint https://server-a.com/receive-webhooks. That endpoint expects a basic auth header.Server A also has a tool that can generate users and passwords, that the receive-webhooks endpoint is able to validate.The system administrator of Server A will now perform the following steps:

Generate an user and password with Server A
Create a subscription with CloudSorts WebHook system using as the URL https://<user>:<password>@server-a.com/receive-webhooks

When the CloudSort system sends a WebHook payload to the URL, it will parse the authentication section (before the @) into a Basic Authentication header and attach it to the request.Server A can validate that header and reject any request that is using an invalid, destroyed or non-existent users and passwords.Advanced Usage
More advanced usage of the WebHooks is available, to allow the use of different protocols for consumer targets, as well as modify format and deal with exceptions.The following advanced configurations are available:
Non-HTTP Targets
The examples in this guide assume the use of an HTTP(s) endpoint that receives the WebHook events.The CloudSort system provides alternative protocols of communication to facilitate connectivity with different systems.At the moment, the following protocols are supported:

http(s)
(s)ftp

To switch a WebHook Subscription from e.g.HTTPS to SFTP, all that's necessary is to change the url property of the subscription payload to follow the following pattern: sftp://<username>:<password>@<sftp-host>:<port>/path/to/upload/to. The system will automatically write files into the given directory containing the payloads of the WebHook Events.It is possible to customize the filenames the system generates, for more information and guidance regarding that, please reach out to your support contact.Non-JSON Format
The system also allows to modify the format in which the WebHooks are sending payloads.The following formats are available:

JSON (default)
CSV

It is important to note, that the CSV format is only provided as a legacy tool, and does not contain the full depth of data as e.g.the JSON format due to limitations of the CSV data layout.Some formats can additionally be customized with specific dialects, e.g.a custom set of CSV header names, to make use of this feature, please reach out to your support contact.","textTemplate":"","metadataSeparator":"
","type":"TEXT","hash":"oau4pQoUf5NVAz/3pzcnPBO6sp+Ey/NNSza6WvOs6ps="}
